page.title: 06Croxteth Hall
page.content: Until 1972 Croxteth Hall and Country Park belonged to the Earl of Sefton. The last Earl died in 1972, and left no-one to inherit it. 535 acres of his estate became Croxteth Country Park and the remainder was sold for housing development. One small section was taken over by a TV company to make the regular series called 'Brookside', shown twice a week on Channel 4. Croxteth Hall, Walled Gardens, and Rare Breeds Farm are open to the public all year round, as well as the 200 acres of woodland, 300 acres of grassland, and 40 acres of gardens that altogether make up Croxteth Country Park. Altogether they make a superb place to enjoy a day out, with plenty of things to do for parents and children. Jenny O'Brien
